prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: alpha Cen Band 8 (C2 pending)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In case the observation was not made in Cycle 2, we wish to carry it over to Cycle 3, as the Band 8 data may reveal crucial information. B8 is in the middle of a knee in the SED, noticed already in our Herschel data, but fully reinforced by ALMA.
This should of course be conditional, i.e., if the observation was made already during C2, it should be skipped from the present proposal, reducing the time request by 0.4 hr.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: as these are continuum observations, we can use the standard continuum setup.
point sources, separated by 4.0" (2015.5-2016.5) implying <1.7" suffices to separate them. Therefore, any of the offered configuration can be used.

continuum, no strong lines expected
in order to be able to determine accurate spectral indices within the band, we request an S/N~25 per spectral window (50 over the band)
as these are continuum observations, we can use the standard continuum setup.

Point sources separated by 10.4" to 10.7" (2015.5-2016.5) implying <3.5" suffices to separate them; therefore, any (extended) configuration can be used.
For the Band3 observations, Sirius A, with a diameter of 1.5 mas, is the largest of the stars. The stellar disk will remain unresolved for any configuration.

continuum, no strong lines expected;
in order to be able to determine accurate spectral indices within the band, we request an S/N of roughly 10 per spectral window (25 over the band);
as these are continuum observations, we can use the standard continuum setup.
single point source in the field; therefore, the resolution of < 3.3" suffices and any configuration can be used.

Continuum, no strong lines expected. First detection experiment; the somewhat uncertain flux estimate justifies the requested S/N ~ 10. Based on MAMBO 1.2 mm data (reference [9]) we infer that, at the center of the hole in the disk, the photosphere contributes 0.08 mJy to the extrapolated 0.18 mJy, the excess being of chromospheric origin.
as these are continuum observations, we can use the standard continuum setup.
point sources; separated by 4.0-4.2" (2015.5-2016.5) implying < 1.7" suffices to separate them. Therefore, any (somewhat extended) configuration can be used.
continuum, no strong lines expected; in order to be able to determine accurate spectral indices within the band, we request an S/N of roughly 10 per spectral window (25 over the band).
as these are continuum observations, we can use the standard continuum setup.
single point source in the field; therefore, the resolution < 3.3" suffices and any (extended) configuration can be used.
continuum, no strong lines expected; first detection experiment, the somewhat uncertain flux estimate justifies the requested S/N ~ 10.
as these are continuum observations, we can use the standard continuum setup.

single point source in the field; the inner hole in the disk has a size larger than 1" (range from 1" to 10", refs. [7], [11]); therefore the resolution < 1.0" suffices and any (extended) configuration can be used.

Continuum, no strong lines expected. First detection experiment, the somewhat uncertain flux estimate justifies the requested S/N ~10.
Any possible disk contribution will be resolved out or have too low surface brightness.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA observations of the Sun are foreseen in the not too distant future. At ALMA wavelengths, much of the focus will be on resolved regions of the active Sun. An integrated picture of the physical phenomena and processes will be provided by non-resolved stars. We have initiated the observation of stars with ALMA with the first successful detection at all wavelengths of the binary alpha Centauri, the nearest to the Sun. With respect to the Sun, these observations revealed both similarities and distinct differences, providing valuable input to theorists and modellers. However, these observations also confirmed that the detectability of stellar chromospheres are optimized in Band 3. In this proposal, we request therefore a few hours of ALMA time for Band 3 observation of the nearest stars, which will result in signal-to-noise ratios of at least five. This will provide a long desired synergy, putting the Sun and other stars into astrophysical context. We also request one non-standard observation, in case it has not been made in Cycle 2, viz. the only remaining but highly important Band 8 observations of alpha Centauri.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00170.S The cool chromospheres of alpha Centauri Liseau, R.
